same
I'm a "float first" kind of guy

well I mean "float first after recall"
because I always recall
well almost always
oh i see
you know me
I usually recall first then if I have no good upgrades at my next campfire then I'll upgrade this. Or if there is an early shop in a really good path I'll upgrade this first.
I feel like float is one of those upgrades where it feels pretty bad for the first act, but by act 3 it gets so much better.
but in act 3 you have better upgrades
it lets you activate Spirit Brand more easily
which helps a lot in act 1

messages.content: Sorry I haven't played hexa in a hot minute
i don't think it helps activate in act 1 that much
card order usually solves the restriction of being forced to advance
Alright enough about float, this is the sear discussion
i was mostly hoping to hear from people who do like the sear upgrade at the first campfire
i remember there being a fair amount of them
I'll occasionally do it if recall isn't a good option, but otherwise no
its like a strike upgrade except you dont have to play the strike to get value out of it
i wouldnt upgrade this card lol
I mean it's a 4 damage upgrade which is pretty good, and if you play it the first cycle then exhaust it the 2nd, that's 28 damage which can get you through most act 1 fights
or at least do a lot to act 1 fights
the problem is is that it's 4 damage later

some scattered thoughts:
* Hexaghost has too many starting cards that don't do very much. I would like to see them looked at again, especially because it is surprisingly challenging to proc the attack ghostflame but there's almost double the number of skills in the starting deck.
* 10 Soulburn for free is at least decent early damage, and the 3 turn timer doesn't always matter because the first ghostflame applies soulburn. 
* Sear highlights a pretty major issue with Afterlife because I barely ever play it twice. Maybe once or twice a run against Act 1 elites. If I play it twice, I may also be risking not drawing it before soulburn detonates, meaning it'd take another 3 turns to go off. Even with a 10 card starting deck, that's a 25% chance to whiff. And Hexa starts with 12.
I've played Sear several times before
but yeah
it's very rare you really WANT to play it
also btw Hexa has 11 card starting deck
and one of those cards is cantrip
starting with a cantrip is probably even weirder though
good point
would sear being turned into a normal attack "deal X damage. Apply Y soulburn" and maybe without afterlife solve those issues?
<t~toasty>
we have Firestarter for that
yeah firestarter but it's basic now
iirc Michael tried that already with <Fast Forward>

If ( **Ignite** ) the current Ghostflame~~-  is not Ignited, **Ignite** it -~~ .

messages.content: This would help the attack ratio, although i'm not sure being forced to keep a weak attack/soulburn card is a good thing. The afterlife isn't the main problem with the card; afterlife in general is just too strong because you get free value out of decent cards. But Sear is just weak so I don't want to play it and would rather just let it exhaust early, and afterlife applying soulburn anyway is just a nice bonus. Also the starter deck would still be too big.
well perhaps make Float a 1 cost attack?
sticking some damage upon it obviously
it's funny because i was thinking it would be good to combine 2 of the starter cards but they already tried Fast Forward lul

messages.content: Well, about type ratio, some time ago there was a discussion in dev channels about changing cards that apply **Soulburn** directly to just be considered as Attacks, as they basically deal delayed damage.
That sounds hella cursed
<Deadly Poison> isn't an attack, is it?

embeds.title: Deadly Poison
embeds.description:
Common Skill / 1 :e_green: / The Silent

Apply 5 (7) Poison:p_poison:.

messages.content: Well, we agreed that it is possible but it would require a small change to how **Soulburn** works, and how it interacts with things like **Strength** and **Vigor**.
Soulburn being affected by Strength sounds weird as fuck
Well, major changes always sound weird. Especially if they are ment to solve a problem that is created by a card pool.

I mean:
it sounds weird because it goes against basegame convention
Generally idea to fix that is to make **<Soulburn>** say that it is a type of damage, and affected by **Block**.

embeds.title: Soulburn
embeds.description:
Keyword

After 3 turns, a Soulburn:p_soulburn:ed enemy loses HP, removing the Soulburn:p_soulburn: effect.

messages.content: oh
so it literally becomes delayed attack damage
that sounds like a time eater thing
So cards would say "Deal ? **Soulburn**."
Kinda, but everything that is delayed sounds like it could work on the Time Eater.
I don't mind this, especially because hexaghost's physical damage modifiers don't usually do much

one vulnerable card, strength from bolstering ghostflame and burning question, and vigor from ghost lash, and most of the time all those go to waste because all your damage comes from soulburn and ghostflames
